thread.title: Clive Lewis quits Labour frontbench to vote against Government's Brexit bill
thread.title_full: Clive Lewis quits Labour frontbench to vote against Government's Brexit bill

author: Jamie Bullen
title: Clive Lewis quits Labour frontbench to vote against Government's Brexit bill
text:
Wednesday 8 February 2017 22:13 GMT Click to followThe Evening Standard Resigned: Clive Lewis has quit the shadow cabinet 
Labour frontbencher Clive Lewis has sensationally quit the shadow cabinet ahead of the Government’s Brexit bill. 
The shadow business secretary has defied Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn's three-line whip to oppose the European Union (Notification of Withdrawal) Bill at its third Commons reading. 
In a statement he said: "When I became the MP for Norwich South, I promised my constituents I would be 'Norwich's voice in Westminster not Westminster's voice in Norwich'. 
"I therefore cannot, in all good conscience, vote for something I believe will ultimately harm the city I have the honour to represent, love and call home. 
"It is therefore with a heavy heart that I have decided to resign from the shadow cabinet." Big thank you to all the kind words & love shown tonight.Hell of a week. Now let's get on with taking the fight to the Tories #A50Bill pic.twitter.com/TMU91aqPpX — Clive Lewis MP (@labourlewis) 8 February 2017 
The resignation is a major blow for Mr Corbyn who faces a possible revolt at his insistence for MPs to support the Government's bill. 
The bill will allow Theresa May to begin withdrawal talks under Article 50 of the EU treaties. 
Mr Lewis backed the bill at its second reading last week but warned he would not do so again unless the legislation was amended by Labour. Labour MP quits frontbench over Corbyn's order to support Brexit bill 
When the final potential amendment was voted down on Wednesday evening, a swift statement was issued which confirmed he had stepped down. 
Mr Lewis becomes the latest Labour frontbencher to quit the shadow cabinet over Mr Corbyn's three-line whip following the departures of Tulip Siddiq, Dawn Butler and Rachael Maskell. Fresh blow for Corbyn as two Labour frontbenchers quit over Brexit 
Mr Corbyn said: “I would like to thank Clive for his work in the shadow cabinet, which has underlined what an asset he is to the Labour party and our movement. 
“I understand the difficulties MPs representing constituencies which voted remain have in relation to the European Union withdrawal bill. MPs have a duty to represent their constituents as well as their party. 
"However, the Labour party respects the outcome of the EU referendum, so we have asked all Labour MPs to vote for the bill at its third reading tonight.” 
The bill was passed after MPs voted 494 to 122 in favour, a majority of 372. More about:
